name: Historic Sankore University
description: One of the world's first universities, Sankore was a center of Islamic learning and housed over 700,000 manuscripts. This UNESCO World Heritage site represents the golden age of Timbuktu's intellectual prominence.

name: Djinguereber Mosque
address: Rue de la Mosquée, Timbuktu, Mali
description: Built in 1327, this iconic mud-brick mosque is one of the oldest in West Africa. Its distinctive architecture and historical significance make it a must-visit landmark in Timbuktu.

name: Timbuktu Manuscripts Museum
description: Home to thousands of ancient manuscripts covering subjects from astronomy to poetry. These documents showcase Timbuktu's role as a center of learning and trade in medieval Africa.

name: Niger River Port
description: The historic port that connected Timbuktu to the Niger River trade routes. Today it remains an important transportation hub and offers scenic views of traditional boats and river life.

name: Grand Market (Grand Marché)
address: Avenue du Grand Marché, Timbuktu, Mali
description: A bustling marketplace where locals trade everything from traditional crafts to spices. Experience the vibrant culture and find unique souvenirs representing Timbuktu's trading heritage.

name: Sidi Yahya Mosque
description: Founded in the 15th century, this mosque features unique Sudanese architecture. Legend says its doors remained sealed for centuries until the right holy man arrived.

name: Traditional Salt Mines
address: Northeast of Timbuktu, Taghaza Region, Mali
description: Ancient salt mines that were crucial to Timbuktu's prosperity. These mines supplied salt across the Sahara and remain active today, showcasing traditional mining techniques.

name: Flame of Peace Monument
address: Place de la Paix, Timbuktu, Mali
description: A modern monument commemorating the peace process in Mali. This striking landmark represents hope for the future while honoring Timbuktu's resilient spirit.
